metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: You can limit the number of records returned from the query, by using the "LIMIT" statement:
content.html: You can limit the number of records returned from the query, by using the "LIMIT" statement:

content.code_html:
var mysql = require('mysql');

var con = mysql.createConnection({
  host: "localhost",
  user: "yourusername",
  password: "yourpassword",
  database: "mydb"
});

con.connect(function(err) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var sql = "SELECT * FROM customers LIMIT 5";
  con.query(sql, function (err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
  });
});

content.text: Save the code above in a file called "demo_db_limit.js" and run the file:
content.html: Save the code above in a file called "demo_db_limit.js" and run the file:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>node demo_db_limit.js

content.text: Which will give you this result:

content.code:
[
  { id: 1, name: 'John', address: 'Highway 71'},
  { id: 
2, name: 'Peter', address: 'Lowstreet 4'},
  { id: 3, name: 'Amy', 
address: 'Apple st 652'},
  { id: 4, name: 'Hannah', address: 
'Mountain 21'},
  { id: 5, name: 'Michael', address: 'Valley 345'}
]
content.code_html:
[
  { id: 1, name: 'John', address: 'Highway 71'},
  { id: 2, name: 'Peter', address: 'Lowstreet 4'},
  { id: 3, name: 'Amy', address: 'Apple st 652'},
  { id: 4, name: 'Hannah', address: 'Mountain 21'},
  { id: 5, name: 'Michael', address: 'Valley 345'}
]

content.text: If you want to return five records, starting from the third record, you can use the "OFFSET" keyword:
content.html: If you want to return five records, starting from the third record, you can use the "OFFSET" keyword:

content.code_html:
var mysql = require('mysql');

var con = mysql.createConnection({
  host: "localhost",
  user: "yourusername",
  password: "yourpassword",
  database: "mydb"
});

con.connect(function(err) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var sql = "SELECT * FROM customers LIMIT 5 OFFSET 2";
  con.query(sql, function (err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
  });
});

content.text: Note: "OFFSET 2", means starting from the third position, not the second!
content.html: Note: "OFFSET 2", means starting from the third position, not the second!

content.text: Save the code above in a file called "demo_db_offset.js" and run the file:
content.html: Save the code above in a file called "demo_db_offset.js" and run the file:

content.code_html: C:\Users\Your Name>node demo_db_offset.js

content.text: Which will give you this result:

content.code:
[
  { id: 3, name: 'Amy', 
address: 'Apple st 652'},
  { id: 4, name: 'Hannah', address: 
'Mountain 21'},
  { id: 5, name: 'Michael', address: 'Valley 345'},
  
{ id: 6, name: 'Sandy', address: 'Ocean blvd 2'},
  { id: 7, name: 'Betty', 
address: 'Green Grass 1'}
]
content.code_html:
[
  { id: 3, name: 'Amy', address: 'Apple st 652'},
  { id: 4, name: 'Hannah', address: 'Mountain 21'},
  { id: 5, name: 'Michael', address: 'Valley 345'},
  { id: 6, name: 'Sandy', address: 'Ocean blvd 2'},
  { id: 7, name: 'Betty', address: 'Green Grass 1'}
]

content.text: You can also write your SQL statement like this "LIMIT 2, 5" which returns the same as the offset example above:
content.html: You can also write your SQL statement like this "LIMIT 2, 5" which returns the same as the offset example above:

content.code_html:
var mysql = require('mysql');

var con = mysql.createConnection({
  host: "localhost",
  user: "yourusername",
  password: "yourpassword",
  database: "mydb"
});

con.connect(function(err) {
  if (err) throw err;
  var sql = "SELECT * FROM customers LIMIT 2, 5";
  con.query(sql, function (err, result) {
    if (err) throw err;
    console.log(result);
  });
});

content.text: Note: The numbers are reversed: "LIMIT 2, 5" is the same as "LIMIT 5 OFFSET 2"
content.html: Note: The numbers are reversed: "LIMIT 2, 5" is the same as "LIMIT 5 OFFSET 2"
